senses.de: To avoid doing something, especially something unpleasant or undesirable.
senses.ex: I managed to get out of doing the dishes by saying I had a headache.
cl: get out of going to a meeting
get out of a bad habit

Tips.title: Avoiding obligations
Tips.description: Use 'get out of' when you successfully avoid a responsibility or task.
Tips.example: He got out of attending the conference by claiming illness.

Tips.title: Escaping undesirable situations
Tips.description: Use 'get out of' to describe escaping a negative experience or predicament.
Tips.example: She got out of a speeding ticket by being polite to the officer.

senses.de: To leave or exit a place, especially a vehicle.
senses.ex: Get out of the car now!

Tips.title: Exiting vehicles
Tips.description: Use 'get out of' when referring to leaving a vehicle.
Tips.example: They got out of the taxi and headed into the hotel.

Tips.title: Leaving locations
Tips.description: Use 'get out of' to describe exiting various places.
Tips.example: I need to get out of this stuffy room.

avoid.wordDefinition: 'Avoid' is more formal and emphasizes intentional prevention, while 'get out of' suggests finding a way to escape an existing obligation or situation.

escape.wordDefinition: 'Escape' often implies a more dramatic or urgent departure from a dangerous or confining situation, while 'get out of' can be used for more mundane situations.
